message_1:
Here is a precise numerical problem for a math student studying Floer homology and its applications:

Consider the two knots K and J that are depicted in the following link: https://i.stack.imgur.com/vU6jZ.png. Suppose we want to compute the Floer homology of the knot complement of K with respect to J, denoted as FH(K, J). Suppose further that the Alexander polynomial of K is given by ΔK(t) = t^3 - t^2 - 2t - 1. Calculate the rank and torsion of FH(K,J) over the field Z/2Z.
message_2:
To compute the rank and torsion of FH(K, J) over the field Z/2Z, we can use the Rasmussen invariant s(K), which is an integer-valued knot invariant that can be computed from the knot Floer homology. The Rasmussen invariant is related to the rank of the knot Floer homology by the following formula:

rank(FH(K, J)) = |s(K) - s(J)|

The Rasmussen invariant is also related to the Alexander polynomial by the following inequality:

|s(K)| ≤ deg(ΔK(t))

Given the Alexander polynomial of K, ΔK(t) = t^3 - t^2 - 2t - 1, we have deg(ΔK(t)) = 3. Therefore, we know that |s(K)| ≤ 3.

Unfortunately, without more information about the knots K and J, we cannot compute the exact values of s(K) and s(J), and thus cannot compute the rank of FH(K, J) over Z/2Z.

As for the torsion of FH(K, J) over Z/2Z, knot Floer homology is known to have no torsion over this field. Therefore, the torsion of FH(K, J) over Z/2Z is trivial.
